1.1 Merging onto the Freeway.Description: The autonomous vehicle (AV) approaches the freeway on-ramp during peak rush hour. The on-ramp is a single-lane, uphill incline leading to a short acceleration lane due to urban infrastructure constraints. The freeway traffic is flowing at high speeds with minimal spacing between vehicles, offering few suitable gaps for merging. Vehicles in the rightmost lane of the freeway are traveling close together, with drivers reluctant to adjust speed or change lanes to accommodate merging traffic. The AV must accurately assess the speed and distance of oncoming vehicles, adjust its acceleration appropriately, and execute a safe merge maneuver without causing disruption to the flow of traffic or compromising safety.

While attempting to merge onto the freeway, the AV encounters drivers in the adjacent lane who are unresponsive to its merging signals. Despite using turn indicators and positioning itself for a merge, nearby vehicles maintain their speed or even accelerate to prevent the AV from entering the lane. The traffic conditions are moderate, but driver behavior is aggressive. The AV must navigate this challenging social driving situation by finding an appropriate gap, potentially adjusting its merging strategy, such as slowing down to merge behind or accelerating to merge ahead, all while ensuring safety and compliance with traffic laws.

As the AV proceeds onto the on-ramp leading to the freeway, the vehicle directly ahead abruptly comes to a complete stop, possibly due to mechanical issues or sudden obstruction. The on-ramp is a single-lane with no shoulder or safe area to maneuver around the stopped vehicle. Traffic behind the AV is also entering the on-ramp, creating potential risk of rear-end collisions. The AV must quickly detect the unexpected stop, decelerate safely to avoid a collision, and determine the best course of action, which may include stopping and waiting, alerting following vehicles, or, if possible, safely navigating around the obstruction.

The AV is merging onto a freeway where the acceleration lane is unusually short because of construction work that has temporarily reduced the length of the merge area. Warning signs indicate the lane ends earlier than normal. The AV must quickly adjust its speed to match that of the freeway traffic within a limited distance. If the traffic is heavy, finding a suitable gap becomes more challenging. The AV needs to decide whether to rapidly accelerate to merge ahead of an approaching vehicle or decelerate to merge behind, all while ensuring a smooth and safe entry onto the freeway without impeding other vehicles.

The AV approaches an on-ramp equipped with ramp metering traffic signals designed to regulate the flow of vehicles entering the freeway. On this occasion, the ramp meters are malfunctioning, displaying erratic signals or remaining unlit altogether. Some drivers are stopping at the non-functioning lights, while others proceed without stopping, causing unpredictable traffic behavior on the on-ramp. The AV must interpret the situation, decide whether to stop or proceed, and adjust its merging strategy accordingly, all while adhering to traffic laws and ensuring safety.

The AV is on an on-ramp that converges with another on-ramp from a different road, both leading onto the same acceleration lane. Several vehicles from both ramps are attempting to merge onto the freeway simultaneously, creating a convergence point with potential for side-by-side merging conflicts. The acceleration lane is of standard length but is congested due to the volume of merging traffic. The AV must navigate this complex scenario by anticipating the actions of adjacent merging vehicles, adjusting its speed and position to safely merge onto the freeway without causing collisions or impeding traffic flow.

Upon approaching its planned on-ramp to enter the freeway, the AV encounters unexpected closure signs due to construction, an accident, or other obstructions completely blocking the entrance. There are no prior warnings or suggested detours provided. The AV must quickly update its route, identifying an alternative on-ramp or route to reach its destination. This requires recalculating the navigation path, considering traffic conditions, and ensuring compliance with traffic laws while executing the rerouting maneuver, which may involve complex urban driving.

While entering the on-ramp, the AV is behind one or more slow-moving vehicles, such as heavy trucks or vehicles towing trailers, which are accelerating at a significantly lower rate than typical traffic. The on-ramp and acceleration lane are single-lane with no opportunity to overtake safely before merging onto the freeway. The freeway traffic is moving at high speeds, and the slow pace of the vehicles ahead affects the AV's ability to match the speed of freeway traffic for a smooth merge. The AV must adjust its merging strategy, possibly by increasing following distance, preparing for a longer acceleration period, and finding a safe gap to merge without causing disruption.

The AV is preparing to merge onto the freeway when its sensors detect an oncoming vehicle traveling the wrong way, entering the freeway via the off-ramp and heading directly towards exiting traffic. This unexpected and hazardous situation requires immediate action. The AV must quickly assess the safest response, which may include stopping safely, alerting other drivers via signals or horn, and potentially contacting emergency services. The AV must also adjust its own merging plan to avoid the wrong-way vehicle and ensure the safety of its passengers and other road users.

The AV is in the acceleration lane, preparing to merge onto the freeway, when it encounters vehicles behind it using the merge lane as an extension of the freeway's rightmost lane. These vehicles are traveling at high speeds, overtaking other vehicles in the merge lane, and potentially cutting off merging traffic. The AV must navigate this misuse of the merge lane, which increases the risk of side-swipe collisions and reduces the space and time available for a safe merge. The AV needs to monitor fast-approaching vehicles from behind, adjust its speed accordingly, and find a safe gap in freeway traffic while being cautious of vehicles improperly using the merge lane.

1.2 Exiting the Freeway.Description: A vehicle suddenly cuts in front of the AV to take an exit.
Backup on the exit ramp causes abrupt slowdowns on the freeway.
The AV misses its exit and must choose whether to continue or attempt a safe lane change.
A vehicle cuts across lanes at the last second to exit while the AV is also exiting.
The intended exit ramp is closed, requiring immediate route adjustment.
Heavy congestion causes exit ramp traffic to back up onto freeway lanes.
Inadequate or misleading exit signs lead to last-minute lane changes.
Exits are closely spaced, requiring sequential lane changes in a short distance.

2.1 Lane Changing.Description: Vehicles make sudden lane changes into the AV’s lane with minimal signaling.
Drivers accelerate to prevent the AV from merging into their lane.
Fast-approaching vehicles in the AV’s blind spot during a planned lane change.
A vehicle re-enters the lane from the shoulder unexpectedly.
Adverse weather renders lane markings invisible, complicating lane changes.
Navigating rules regarding HOV lanes with limited entry and exit points.
Lanes change direction based on time of day, requiring adaptation.

2.2 Lane Keeping.Description: Adjacent vehicles drift into the AV’s lane due to distraction or impairment.
Temporary narrowing requires precise lane keeping, often due to construction.
Height differences between the lane and shoulder affect stability.
Oversized vehicles occupy more than one lane, requiring precise lane keeping.

3.1 Aggressive or Erratic Drivers.Description: The vehicle ahead brakes hard without warning.
A following vehicle is too close, reducing safe stopping distance.
Swerving or unpredictable speed changes by nearby vehicles.
Aggressive behavior towards the AV, such as unsafe passing.
A driver intentionally brakes suddenly to provoke a reaction.
Drivers swerving due to distraction, potentially encroaching into the AV's lane.
Erratic speed and lane position from drivers under the influence.
Vehicles without functioning brake lights or turn signals.

3.2 Non-Standard Road Users.Description: Motorcycles pass between lanes during congestion.
Sudden lane changes or weaving through traffic by motorcycles.
A bicycle illegally on the shoulder moving slowly.
Individuals walking near freeway entrances or exits.
A pedestrian attempts to cross or walks along the freeway.
Pedestrians on overpasses exhibit risky behavior.
Unauthorized users on the shoulder or lanes.
Animals are herded across the freeway under supervision.
Individuals riding horses along the freeway shoulder.
Unauthorized users attempt high-speed runs on the freeway.

4. Obstacle Avoidance.Description: Objects like tire fragments appear suddenly in the AV’s lane.
Items fall off a vehicle ahead, requiring evasive action.
A stalled vehicle partially obstructs the lane.
Damaged barriers encroach into the roadway, narrowing lanes.
Traffic control devices are out of place, causing confusion.
An animal crosses the freeway, prompting sudden reactions.
Deer or livestock cross the freeway unexpectedly.
A tree falls onto the roadway due to weather.
Objects fall from overpasses onto the roadway.

5. Traffic Congestion Scenarios.Description: Frequent starting and stopping due to congestion.
Unexpected slow traffic without a visible cause.
Multiple vehicles merge into the same lane simultaneously.
A convoy travels slowly, affecting normal traffic flow.
Heavy traffic due to evacuation orders leads to abnormal patterns.
Nearby events cause sudden influxes of traffic onto the freeway.

6. Road Construction Zones.Description: Lane closures require merging and prompt aggressive behaviors.
Slow-moving construction vehicles enter or exit the freeway.
The AV must navigate without clear lane demarcations.
Confusion due to outdated or temporary lane markings.
Malfunctioning equipment moves into active lanes.
Materials are left in lanes, causing hazards.
Construction workers operate close to moving traffic.
Construction areas change rapidly with new patterns.

7. Road Sign and Marking Issues.Description: Conflicting speed limits or directional signs.
Variable message signs change information suddenly.
Old or temporary markings conflict with current lanes.
Signs display incorrect information due to vandalism or errors.
Signs display incorrect or nonsensical information.
Vegetation or obstructions hide important traffic signs.

8. Road Geometry Challenges.Description: Handling tight turns at freeway speeds.
Sudden inclines or declines affect vehicle dynamics.
Multi-level interchanges with unusual merging patterns.
Avoiding areas with low clearance if carrying tall loads.
A lane ends abruptly without much warning.

9. Environmental Factors.Description: Trucks swerve due to wind, encroaching into the AV’s lane.
Rain, fog, or snow affect visibility and road traction.
The AV enters dense fog, reducing visibility.
Low sun angles cause glare affecting sensors.
Rapid water accumulation leads to standing water.
Wildfire smoke reduces visibility and air quality.

10. Vehicle Malfunctions and Unusual Beh.Description: A vehicle ahead has a blowout, causing unpredictable movements.
A vehicle slows down abruptly due to engine failure.
Cargo shifts or falls onto the roadway.
Vehicles travel significantly below the speed limit.
Skidding or overcorrection leads to unpredictable hazards.
A vehicle ahead catches fire, causing erratic behavior.
A vehicle moves without an apparent driver.
A vehicle continues driving despite tire failure.
A stalled vehicle is located just beyond a curve or hillcrest.

11. Erroneous or Illegal Actions by Othe.Description: A driver reverses after missing an exit.
A vehicle enters the freeway going the wrong direction.
Last-second lane crossings to reach an exit.
Illegal U-turns or stopping on the freeway.
Vehicles race on the freeway, weaving through traffic.
A vehicle fleeing law enforcement drives recklessly.
A driver intentionally blocks lanes to impede traffic.
Drivers illegally use the shoulder to pass traffic.

12. Complex Road Configurations.Description: Navigating entry and exit points with specific rules.
Dealing with variable speed limits or access restrictions.
Forced merges due to lane closures.
Traffic is rerouted onto surface streets due to incidents.
Lanes switch direction during peak hours.
Lanes switch between HOV and toll use based on conditions.

13. Emergency Vehicles and Situations.Description: Officers weave across lanes to slow traffic.
A sudden stop ahead causes a ripple effect.
A small aircraft makes an emergency landing on the freeway.
Military vehicles travel with specific patterns and security.
Emergency services use part of the freeway, altering flow.

14. Behavioral Prediction Challenges.Description: Swerving to avoid unseen obstacles or due to distraction.
Rapid acceleration or deceleration without apparent reason.
Sudden changes due to construction or events.
Modified vehicles may not be recognized properly.
Interaction with other AVs that may behave unpredictably.

14. Behavioral Prediction Challenges.Scenario: Inconsistent Behavior Due to Driverless Testing
14. Behavioral Prediction Challenges.Description: Encountering test vehicles not following standard protocols.

15. Unusual Road Users.Description: Small animals dart across the freeway.
Individuals attempt to cross or walk along the freeway.
Motorcycles pass between lanes during congestion.
Individuals riding horses along the freeway shoulder.
Individuals running across the freeway as a prank.

16. Multi-Vehicle Interactions.Description: Navigating when surrounded with minimal gaps.
A collision ahead causes multiple vehicles to brake hard.
Skids or overcorrections create unpredictable hazards.
A multi-vehicle collision blocks multiple lanes.
Groups intentionally slow traffic as a form of protest.
Multiple vehicles spread across lanes driving slowly.

17. Sudden Changes in Traffic Regulation.Description: Rapid reductions due to construction or special events.
Variable signs change speed limits or lane usage.
Authorities close the freeway without prior notice.
Law enforcement sets up checkpoints requiring stops.
Traffic is halted to allow passage of a VIP convoy.

18. Unexpected Vehicle Entries.Description: A vehicle abruptly re-enters traffic without acceleration.
Entry from unauthorized areas like maintenance accesses.
Unattended vehicles roll onto the freeway.
Vehicles enter from non-standard access points.

19. Environmental Factors Affecting Othe.Description: Strong winds cause vehicles to drift into adjacent lanes.
Adverse weather leads to erratic driving by others.
Sudden hail affects control and causes drivers to stop.
Ash reduces visibility and affects systems.
Severe winds cause unpredictable driver reactions.

20. Emergency Maneuvers by Other Vehicle.Description: A vehicle swerves suddenly, requiring the AV to adjust.
A vehicle stops abruptly without an apparent cause.
A driver experiences a medical issue, leading to erratic driving.
Parts of signs or bridges fall onto the roadway.

21. Unusual Load Carriers.Description: Homemade trailers or oversized items not secured properly.
Vehicles exceed safe limits, affecting stability.
A tanker leaks hazardous material, requiring caution.

22. Technology Failures.Description: The AV loses GPS signal, affecting navigation.
Mud, snow, or debris obstructs sensors.
Attempts to hack the AV's systems cause incorrect behavior.

23. Infrastructure Failures.Description: Malfunctioning lights cause confusion at ramp meters.
Issues require sudden closures or cause debris.
Darkness on sections of the freeway due to failures.

24. Unpredictable Human Factors.Description: Individuals try to interfere with the AV intentionally.
Drivers exhibiting road rage or distress.
Coordinated groups block traffic to protest AV technology.

25. Natural Disasters.Description: Sudden shaking affects stability and may damage roads.
Debris blocks lanes or the entire roadway.
Evacuation orders require rapid and coordinated movement.

26. Cross-Border or Jurisdictional Chall.Description: Crossing into areas where laws or signage differ.
Approaching international borders requires compliance with procedures.

27. Unusual Weather Phenomena.Description: Sudden darkness causes distraction or erratic behavior.
Blowing dust reduces visibility to near zero.
Rapid ice accumulation creates slippery conditions.

28. Space Debris or Meteor Showers.Description: Debris impacts the ground, causing unexpected hazards.

29. Unplanned Human Activities.Description: Large groups obstruct the freeway as a demonstration.
Sudden gatherings spill onto the freeway, causing disruptions.

30. Interactions with Law Enforcement.Description: Police stop vehicles randomly for inspections.
Law enforcement sets up roadblocks, necessitating rerouting.
